description:
Candida tropicalis MYA-3404 is a species of yeast that belongs to the genus Candida. It is a unicellular, eukaryotic microorganism commonly found in the human gastrointestinal tract and other parts of the body.

This specific strain, MYA-3404, is a laboratory-maintained isolate of Candida tropicalis, which has been widely used in scientific research. Candida tropicalis is known to be an opportunistic pathogen, capable of causing infections in immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV/AIDS, cancer, or organ transplants.

The genome of Candida tropicalis MYA-3404 has been sequenced, providing insights into its genetic composition and potential virulence factors. Studies have shown that this strain exhibits various metabolic capabilities, including the ability to utilize a wide range of carbon sources and the production of enzymes involved in pathogenesis.

Candida tropicalis MYA-3404 has been used as a model organism in various research areas, such as antifungal drug development, host-pathogen interactions, and the understanding of fungal pathogenesis mechanisms. Its study has contributed to the advancement of our knowledge about the biology and epidemiology of this clinically relevant yeast species.
